content.body: once I learned that XHR was what those sites were using to make the user experience they gave, I remember talking with people on the browser team and saying to them, Well, clearly now we really need to enable XHR in our browser
But there response at the time was, No, we really don‚Äôt, because what we have now is working

And they were provably right when they said that, because our browser (EZWeb browser) was shipping preinstalled on literally millions of browsers in Japan, and that browser was solving problems for literally millions of people in Japan who were using it every day to do all kinds of things
And we were making great money from it all
But my feeling was still, we can do better than this
The browser was well designed, and worked with content written in XHTML and CSS, not just WML ‚Äî and it even had scripting. But it wasn‚Äôt JavaScript ‚Äî it was WMLScript instead

And I remember people from the browser team patiently telling me that, with just our current stack, we could actually enable developers to create richer user experiences of the kind that were coming out in sites then, in 2004 and 2005 ‚Äî that it in part, just needed developers to start doing some things differently and better (and providers buying more of our server products)

And then into our market came the full Opera browser shipping preinstalled on just one phone, labeled as ‚ÄúPC Site Viewer‚Äù ‚Äî and users in Japan could then, on their mobile phones, access real full web content, from real web sites
with some XHR support in the browser
but for us at Openwave, enabling XHR meant adding support to JavaScript, switching from WMLScript to JavaScript

but the company just did not at all have the economic incentives to invest in doing that ‚Äî we already had the customers shipping our browser on millions of devices, we had a huge number of developers creating content that worked well in it already, and we had millions of users already using it
and the browser PMs and engineers just saw no good strong need for it
‚Ä¶and that‚Äôs when I left and went to work at Opera

among the great things at Opera was that among the engineering team and QA team the default attitude really was ‚Äúwe can do better than this‚Äù, and they were wiling to try out some risky, nutty, unproven ideas ‚Äî and the company management then really supported that (all the way up to Jon von Tetzchner and Haakon, especially)
